elements.content: Chemotherapy remains restricted by its toxic adverse effects and resistance to drugs. The treatment of nitric oxide (NO) combined with imaging-guided physical therapy is a promising alternative for clinical applications. Herein, we report nanoscale metal–organic framework (NMOF) systems to integrate magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, spatiotemporally controllable NO delivery, and photothermal therapy (PTT) as a new means of cancer theranostics. As a proof of concept, the NMOFs are prepared with biocompatible Zr4+ ions and Mn-porphyrin as a bridging ligand. By inserting paramagnetic Mn ions into porphyrin rings, Mn-porphyrin renders the NMOFs strong T 1-weighted MR contrast capacity and high photothermal conversion for efficient PTT. S-Nitrosothiol (SNO) is conjugated to the surfaces of the NMOFs for heat-sensitive NO generation. Moreover, single near-infrared (NIR) light triggers the controllable NO release and PTT simultaneously for their efficient synergistic therapy with one-step operation. Upon intravenous injection, NMOF–SNO shows effective tumor accumulation as exposed by the MR images of the tumor-bearing mice. When exposed to the NIR laser, the tumors of mice injected with NMOF–SNO are completely inhibited, verifying the efficiency of NMOF–SNO. For the first time, Mn-porphyrin NMOFs are developed to be an effective theranostic system for MR imaging-guided controllable NO release and photothermal synergetic therapy under single NIR irradiation.

elements.content: Theranostic, which combines diagnostics and therapeutics to improve the management of healthcare, has driven cancer treatment to a new dimension. Imaging-guided chemotherapy solves the toxicity and adverse effects of chemotherapeutic agents toward normal organs, but the continuous drug delivery may pose another devastating problem, drug resistance. The development of an alternative strategy toward chemotherapy has been one of the critical challenges to provide effective therapy for cancer. Recently, various phototherapies, as “green” treatments with minimal toxicity to normal organs, have been developed, including photothermal therapy (PTT) and photodynamic therapy (PDT). The main obstacle of singlet oxygen (1O2)-based PDT is the local hypoxia of tumor, which is recognized as the characteristic hallmarks to lead to PDT resistance.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Theranostic, which combines diagnostics and therapeutics to improve the management of healthcare, has driven cancer treatment to a new dimension. Imaging-guided chemotherapy solves the toxicity and adverse effects of chemotherapeutic agents toward normal organs, but the continuous drug delivery may pose another devastating problem, drug resistance. The development of an alternative strategy toward chemotherapy has been one of the critical challenges to provide effective therapy for cancer. Recently, various phototherapies, as "green" treatments with minimal toxicity to normal organs, have been developed, including photothermal therapy (PTT) and photodynamic therapy (PDT). The main obstacle of singlet oxygen (1O2)-based PDT is the local hypoxia of tumor, which is recognized as the characteristic hallmarks to lead to PDT resistance.

elements.content: As an emerging treatment to tumor cells, free-radical gas nitric oxide (NO) has drawn widespread attention. The combination of NO therapy with other treatment protocols, such as chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and PDT, has been confirmed to get excellent synergistic effects. Nanoscale metal–organic frameworks (NMOFs), as an efficient platform to combine imaging with cancer therapy together, are easily post-modified. MOFs have currently been used for the delivery of gas NO in terms of their excellent porosity. However, NO gas is toxic and unstable, which makes the preparation of the MOF-NO system difficult. Additionally, they cannot achieve the controlled and targeted NO release. In order to achieve precisely controlled NO release, real-time imaging monitoring and stimuli-responsive NO donors should be integrated together. Consequently, the integration of stimuli-responsive NO donors, imaging guidance, and multimodality therapeutic into NMOFs is expected for their optimal synergistic therapy.

elements.content: Porphyrin NMOFs, including DBP-UiO, PCN-224, or PMOF, have already been designed for PDT or fluorescence imaging because of the integration of the optical properties of free porphyrin. However, fluorescence imaging suffers from low penetration depth; PDT is resisted by the hypoxia environment of the tumor. Fortunately, the incorporation of Mn into porphyrin rings, such as Mn-porphysome, is very promising to design and prepare magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and PTT agents by taking the advantage of MR response of Mn ions and photothermal conversion of Mn-porphyrin.
elements.clean_text: Porphyrin NMOFs, including DBP-UiO, PCN-224, or PMOF, have already been designed for PDT or fluorescence imaging because of the integration of the optical properties of free porphyrin. However, fluorescence imaging suffers from low penetration depth; PDT is resisted by the hypoxia environment of the tumor. Fortunately, the incorporation of Mn into porphyrin rings, such as Mn-porphysome, is very promising to design and prepare magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and PTT agents by taking the advantage of MR response of Mn ions and photothermal conversion of Mn-porphyrin.

elements.content: Herein, we for the first time demonstrate that the incorporation of Mn ions into porphyrin rings is endowed with the capacity of MR contrast and photothermal conversion of the NMOFs without increasing their complexity. To this end, Mn-porphyrin NMOFs were prepared via self-assembling of biocompatible Zr4+ ions and Mn-TCPP (TCPP = tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin). The introduction of Mn ions into TCPP provided the photothermal and MR contrast capacity of the NMOFs simultaneously. The NMOFs were then used to conjugate with S-nitrosothiol (SNO), a type of heat-unstable NO donor. Therefore, MRI-guided NO and photothermal synergistic therapy was realized with the NMOF platform. Importantly, single near-infrared (NIR) irradiation achieves photothermal conversion for PTT and controllable NO release for NO therapy simultaneously with simple operation and less photodamage. After intravenous injection into the mice, NMOF–SNO showed efficient tumor accumulation as revealed with MRI. The tumors of the mice injected with NMOF–SNO were obviously inhibited upon the NIR irradiation, confirming the efficiency of in vivo NO and photothermal synergistic therapy. Low dose of doxorubicin (DOX) administration to the tumor-bearing mice was designed to simulate the drug resistance of the tumor. Later on, normal dose of DOX and NMOF–SNO were used to treat the drug-resistance tumor model. NMOF–SNO showed the complete inhibition of the tumor growth compared to DOX chemotherapy. Therefore, NMOF–SNO composites developed here, as a new kind of biocompatible and effective agent, owned strong MRI capacity, efficient photothermal conversion, and controllable NO release and were free from drug resistance. The results may stimulate the development of a nondrug therapeutics system as the alternative of chemotherapy.

elements.content: N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) was obtained from Concord, Tianjin, China. Acetic acid and zirconium chloride (ZrCl4) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. Ammonia solution (28–30 wt % in water), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 99.9%), 3-mercaptopropyl-trimethoxysilane (MPTES), and t-butyl nitrite were purchased from Meryer Co. Ltd. [5,10,15,20-Tetrakis­(4-methoxycarbonylphenyl)­porphyrinato]-Mn­(III) chloride (MnTCPPCl) was from Chemsoon Co Ltd., Shanghai, China. 3-Amino-4-aminomethyl-2′,7′-difluorescein diacetate (DAFDA) was purchased from the Beyotime Institute of Biotechnology, Shanghai, China. Other reagents were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd. All solutions were prepared by using ultrapure water.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

 N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) was obtained from Concord, Tianjin, China. Acetic acid and zirconium chloride (ZrCl4) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. Ammonia solution (28-30 wt % in water), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 99.9%), 3-mercaptopropyl-trimethoxysilane (MPTES), and t-butyl nitrite were purchased from Meryer Co. Ltd. [5,10,15,20-Tetrakis(4-methoxycarbonylphenyl)porphyrinato]-Mn(III) chloride (MnTCPPCl) was from Chemsoon Co Ltd., Shanghai, China. 3-Amino-4-aminomethyl-2',7'-difluorescein diacetate (DAFDA) was purchased from the Beyotime Institute of Biotechnology, Shanghai, China. Other reagents were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd. All solutions were prepared by using ultrapure water.

elements.content: All the BALB/c mice (18–22 g) used were purchased from the Institute of Hematology & Hospital of Blood Disease, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College with the license no. SCXK-2014-0013, Tianjin, China. The mice were confined in a cage. They had open access to water and solid rodent chow, which was obtained from HFK, Beijing, China. The Institutional Animal Care Committee of Nankai University permitted all the experimental procedure. All the methods were consistent with the related provisions from the Institutional Animal Care Committee of Nankai University.

elements.content: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded using a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer (German). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of NMOFs and NMOF–SNO were obtained on a JEM-2010HR microscope (JEOL, Japan) with an operating voltage of 200 kV. The PTC-10ATG-DTA analyzer was used to represent the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore size of NMOFs were investigated on a Tristar 3000 surface area and pore size analyzer (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA 30093-2901, U.S.A.). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were characterized on a D/max-2500 diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). A UV-3900-visible spectrophotometer (HITACHI, Japan) was used to record the UV–vis absorption spectrum. The hydrodynamic sizes [dynamic light scattering (DLS)] and zeta potentials of NMOFs and NMOF–SNO were tested by a Zetasizer Nano ZS, Malvern, England. The MR images were analyzed by using a MRI system (1.2T, Huantong, Shanghai, China).

elements.content: ZrCl4 (4.16 mg), MnTCPPCl (0.011 mmol L–1), and acetic acid (0.42 mL) were dissolved in 16 mL of DMF using a 20 mL Pyrex vial. Then, the mixture was heated at 120 °C in an air oven for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature, dark green fusiform-shaped NMOFs were obtained and collected by centrifugation (9 mg, 63% yield). Anal. Calcd (%) for NMOFs: C, 56%; H, 2.7%; N, 5.3%. Found: C, 54%; H, 4.3%; N, 4.6%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NMOFs and NMOF-SNO

ZrCl4 (4.16 mg), MnTCPPCl (0.011 mmol L-1), and acetic acid (0.42 mL) were dissolved in 16 mL of DMF using a 20 mL Pyrex vial. Then, the mixture was heated at 120 °C in an air oven for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature, dark green fusiform-shaped NMOFs were obtained and collected by centrifugation (9 mg, 63% yield). Anal. Calcd (%) for NMOFs: C, 56%; H, 2.7%; N, 5.3%. Found: C, 54%; H, 4.3%; N, 4.6%.

elements.content: The above-obtained NMOFs were dissolved in 10 mL of H2O, and 96 μL (0.05 g/mL) of poly­(vinyl pyrrolidone) was added with agitation for 2 h at ambient temperature. Then, the mixture was centrifuged with ethanol and dispersed in 18 mL of ethanol with 0.54 mL of ammonium hydroxide. Subsequently, 34 μL of TEOS was added to the mixture dropwise. Finally, 50 μL of MPTES was added, and the reaction was carried out for 12 h. The resulted thiol-functionalized NMOFs were isolated through centrifugation at 14 000 rpm. The isolated product was washed with ethanol and distilled water and then vacuum-dried for further use.
elements.clean_text: The above-obtained NMOFs were dissolved in 10 mL of H2O, and 96 μL (0.05 g/mL) of poly(vinyl pyrrolidone) was added with agitation for 2 h at ambient temperature. Then, the mixture was centrifuged with ethanol and dispersed in 18 mL of ethanol with 0.54 mL of ammonium hydroxide. Subsequently, 34 μL of TEOS was added to the mixture dropwise. Finally, 50 μL of MPTES was added, and the reaction was carried out for 12 h. The resulted thiol-functionalized NMOFs were isolated through centrifugation at 14000 rpm. The isolated product was washed with ethanol and distilled water and then vacuum-dried for further use.

elements.content: The introduction of the NO donor on NMOFs was achieved by reacting the −SH groups with t-butyl nitrite. A total of 10 mg of NMOF–SH nanocomposites and excess t-butyl nitrite were dispersed in 10 mL of the mixed solution of methanol/toluene (v/v = 1:9) and agitated for 12 h at 25 °C. The synthetic nanocomposites were centrifuged at 14 000 rpm and washed with anhydrous ethanol and ultrapure water three times. The composites were then vacuum-dried for 5 min and stored at −20 °C under dark conditions for further applications.
elements.clean_text: The introduction of the NO donor on NMOFs was achieved by reacting the -SH groups with t-butyl nitrite. A total of 10 mg of NMOF-SH nanocomposites and excess t-butyl nitrite were dispersed in 10 mL of the mixed solution of methanol/toluene (v/v = 1:9) and agitated for 12 h at 25 °C. The synthetic nanocomposites were centrifuged at 14000 rpm and washed with anhydrous ethanol and ultrapure water three times. The composites were then vacuum-dried for 5 min and stored at -20 °C under dark conditions for further applications.

elements.content: To compare the cell internalization of NMOFs and NMOF–SNO, MCF-7 cells were cultured with fresh culture medium containing NMOFs or NMOF–SNO (200 and 400 μg mL–1 based on NMOFs) for 12 h. The cells were gathered, washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) two times, and counted. Finally, 500 μL of PBS was added into the cells and digested with 500 μL of aqua regia for the inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP–AES) measurement. Each experiment was repeated three times.
elements.clean_text:
Cell Internalization, Cytotoxicity, and Phototoxicity of NMOF-SNO

To compare the cell internalization of NMOFs and NMOF-SNO, MCF-7 cells were cultured with fresh culture medium containing NMOFs or NMOF-SNO (200 and 400 μg mL-1 based on NMOFs) for 12 h. The cells were gathered, washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) two times, and counted. Finally, 500 μL of PBS was added into the cells and digested with 500 μL of aqua regia for the inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) measurement. Each experiment was repeated three times.

elements.content: The cytotoxicity and phototoxicity of NMOF–SNO were evaluated with the viability of MCF-7 cells by a standard methyl thiazolyl tetrazolium (MTT) assay. The cells were treated with different methods, and 96-well culture plates were used to incubate the cells with a density of 5 × 103 cells per well in culture medium. The cells were then treated with different concentrations of NMOFs or NMOF–SNO (0, 50, 100, and 200 μg mL–1 based on NMOFs). The cells with only the NIR laser (808 nm, 1.0 W cm–2) and the cells incubated with only NMOF–SNO were selected as the control groups. The PTT group of the cells treated with NMOFs was exposed to 808 nm irradiation for 10 min at the 1.0 W cm–2 level. The synergetic photothermal and gas therapy group of cells incubated with NMOF–SNO was also under NIR stimulation for 10 min (808 nm, 1.0 W cm–2). Then, the plates were maintained at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 air incubator for another 24 h. MTT solution (20 μL 5.0 mg mL–1, BBS) was added to each well. After 3 h, the residual MTT solution was removed. Then, 150 μL of dimethyl sulfoxide (Amresco, America) was added to each well to dissolve the formazan crystals. The absorbance [optical density (OD) value] of each well was measured on a microplate reader (Promega, China) at the wavelength of 550 nm. Cell viability was calculated by the following formula: Cell viability % = ( O D drug / O D control ) × 100 %

The cells were then treated with different concentrations of NMOFs or NMOF-SNO (0, 50, 100, and 200 μg mL-1 based on NMOFs). elements.content: The Griess reagent kit was used to record the NO release behavior of the nanocomposites, which could test the presence of nitrite ions in the solution effectively. The NO gas converted into nitrite in response to the Griess agent, which formed a pinkish diazo compound. UV–vis absorption spectroscopy was used to record the signal at 540 nm.
elements.clean_text:
NO Release in Aqueous Solution and Intracellular NO Staining

The Griess reagent kit was used to record the NO release behavior of the nanocomposites, which could test the presence of nitrite ions in the solution effectively. The NO gas converted into nitrite in response to the Griess agent, which formed a pinkish diazo compound. UV-vis absorption spectroscopy was used to record the signal at 540 nm.

elements.content: The commercial NO indicator, DAFDA, was used to stain NO in cells. MCF-7 cells were cultured in six-well plates with 40 000 cells per well. The cells were treated with the DAFDA solution (5 μM, 1 mL) for 0.5 h when the cells were adherent. Subsequently, the cells were cultured with NMOFs or NMOF–SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs) for 2 h and exposed to the NIR laser for 10 min. Inverted fluorescence microscopy was used to analyze the stained cells.
elements.clean_text: The commercial NO indicator, DAFDA, was used to stain NO in cells. MCF-7 cells were cultured in six-well plates with 40000 cells per well. The cells were treated with the DAFDA solution (5 μM, 1 mL) for 0.5 h when the cells were adherent. Subsequently, the cells were cultured with NMOFs or NMOF-SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL-1 based on NMOFs) for 2 h and exposed to the NIR laser for 10 min. Inverted fluorescence microscopy was used to analyze the stained cells.

elements.content: The NMOFs and NMOF–SNO of MRI were tested at various Mn concentrations (0.076, 0.038, 0.019, 0.0096, and 0.0048 mM) with a 1.2 T MRI system. The T 1 value was recorded with the MRI system. The Mn content of NMOF–SNO was tested with ICP–AES. The r 1 value was the slope of the linear fitting equation between 1/T 1 and the Mn content. The r 2 value was obtained in a similar way. The images were acquired by a 50 mm animal coil and a fat-saturated three-dimensional (3D) gradient-echo imaging sequence. The MRI parameters were set as shown: spin-echo T 1-weighted MRI sequence, field of view (FOV) = 100 × 50 mm2, repetition time (TR)/echo time (TE) = 100.0/8.8 ms, slice thickness = 1 mm, and matrix = 512 × 512, 30.0 °C.
elements.clean_text:
In Vitro and in Vivo MRI with NMOF-SNO

The NMOFs and NMOF-SNO of MRI were tested at various Mn concentrations (0.076, 0.038, 0.019, 0.0096, and 0.0048 mM) with a 1.2 T MRI system. The T 1 value was recorded with the MRI system. The Mn content of NMOF-SNO was tested with ICP-AES. The r 1 value was the slope of the linear fitting equation between 1/T 1 and the Mn content. The r 2 value was obtained in a similar way. The images were acquired by a 50 mm animal coil and a fat-saturated three-dimensional (3D) gradient-echo imaging sequence. The MRI parameters were set as shown: spin-echo T 1-weighted MRI sequence, field of view (FOV) = 100 × 50 mm2, repetition time (TR)/echo time (TE) = 100.0/8.8 ms, slice thickness = 1 mm, and matrix = 512 × 512, 30.0 °C.

elements.content: In vivo MRI was carried out on the same nude mice anesthetized with 200 μL of 4% chloral hydrate. The MR profiles were obtained by fixing the mice on an animal plate in the MRI system after intravenous injection of NMOF–SNO solution (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs) into the mice. The MRI was implemented on a 3.0 T MRI system (GE Signa Excite) using a small animal coil, before and after injection, by a fat-saturated 3D gradient-echo imaging sequence: FOV = 110 mm × 110 mm, TR/TE = 9.7/3.0 ms, FA = 13°, inversion time = 5.0 ms, slice thickness = 1 mm, and matrix = 256 × 256 without gap.
elements.clean_text: In vivo MRI was carried out on the same nude mice anesthetized with 200 μL of 4% chloral hydrate. The MR profiles were obtained by fixing the mice on an animal plate in the MRI system after intravenous injection of NMOF-SNO solution (400 μL, 1 mg mL-1 based on NMOFs) into the mice. The MRI was implemented on a 3.0 T MRI system (GE Signa Excite) using a small animal coil, before and after injection, by a fat-saturated 3D gradient-echo imaging sequence: FOV = 110 mm × 110 mm, TR/TE = 9.7/3.0 ms, FA = 13°, inversion time = 5.0 ms, slice thickness = 1 mm, and matrix = 256 × 256 without gap.

elements.content: In order to confirm the biodistribution of NMOF–SNO, the main organs from the nude mice injected with NMOF–SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs) were sacrificed. After the organs were collected and weighed, they were solubilized in chloroazotic acid with boiling for 2 h. After each sample was diluted with ultrapure water to 5 mL, ICP–AES was used to test the content of Mn. For investigating the excretion of nanocomposites, the mice were caged in metabolic cases, and their urine and feces were collected after injection with NMOF–SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs). Chloroazotic acid was used to digest the urine and feces for the determination of the Mn content with ICP–AES.
elements.clean_text:
Biodistribution and Clearance of NMOF-SNO Nanocomposites

In order to confirm the biodistribution of NMOF-SNO, the main organs from the nude mice injected with NMOF-SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL-1 based on NMOFs) were sacrificed. After the organs were collected and weighed, they were solubilized in chloroazotic acid with boiling for 2 h. After each sample was diluted with ultrapure water to 5 mL, ICP-AES was used to test the content of Mn. For investigating the excretion of nanocomposites, the mice were caged in metabolic cases, and their urine and feces were collected after injection with NMOF-SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL-1 based on NMOFs). Chloroazotic acid was used to digest the urine and feces for the determination of the Mn content with ICP-AES.

elements.content: The efficiency of NO-PTT synergetic therapy of NMOF–SNO was used with the tumor-bearing mice (18–22 g, n = 3 per group), which were anesthetized with 4% chloral hydrate (6 mL kg–1). The mice were divided into five groups. The negative control was treated with saline, whereas the mice treated with NMOF–SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs) without any irradiation and the mice with only NIR light irradiation were considered as two kinds of positive controls. In the PTT group, the mice after injection with NMOF nanocomposites (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs) were exposed to the NIR laser for 10 min (808 nm, 1.0 W cm–2). The synergetic NO and PTT group was injected with NMOF–SNO and irradiated under the NIR laser (1.0 W cm–2, 10 min). The treatment for all the mice of different groups was repeated every 3 days. The tumor sizes and weights of the mice were measured every 2 days. The tumor volumes of the mice were counted as (width2 × length)/2 similar to the previous report. The major organs of mice in different groups were collected. The biotoxicity was investigated by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained images. The mice were weighed in a balance within 14 days.
elements.clean_text:
NO-PTT Dual Therapy of Tumor-Bearing Mice with NMOF-SNO as the Probe

The efficiency of NO-PTT synergetic therapy of NMOF-SNO was used with the tumor-bearing mice (18-22 g, n = 3 per group), which were anesthetized with 4% chloral hydrate (6 mL kg-1). The mice were divided into five groups. The negative control was treated with saline, whereas the mice treated with NMOF-SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL-1 based on NMOFs) without any irradiation and the mice with only NIR light irradiation were considered as two kinds of positive controls. In the PTT group, the mice after injection with NMOF nanocomposites (400 μL, 1 mg mL-1 based on NMOFs) were exposed to the NIR laser for 10 min (808 nm, 1.0 W cm-2). The synergetic NO and PTT group was injected with NMOF-SNO and irradiated under the NIR laser (1.0 W cm-2, 10 min). The treatment for all the mice of different groups was repeated every 3 days. The tumor sizes and weights of the mice were measured every 2 days. The tumor volumes of the mice were counted as (width2 × length)/2 similar to the previous report. The major organs of mice in different groups were collected. The biotoxicity was investigated by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained images. The mice were weighed in a balance within 14 days.

elements.content: The therapy efficiency of NMOF–SNO compared to that of free DOX was also evaluated with the tumor-bearing mice (18–22 g, n = 3 per group) as models. In the control group, the mice were first treated with low-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.2 mg mL–1) every other day and then treated with high-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.6 mg mL–1). The experiment group was first treated with low-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.2 mg mL–1) and then with NMOF–SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1 based on NMOFs) every other day. The tumor sizes and weights of the mice were measured, and the biotoxicity was investigated by H&E stained images to evaluate the drug resistance.

elements.content: A illustrates the fabrication of NMOF–SNO nanocomposites. Solvothermal reaction of ZrCl4, Mn-TCPP, and the modulating reagent acetic acid resulted in the formation of spindle-shaped NMOFs, similar to PCN-223. The size of NMOFs was 60 × 140 nm (B). A relatively narrow size distribution was observed with the diameter of 224.3 nm from their DLS test (Figure S1). High-resolution TEM images revealed the internal structure of the NMOFs with the triangular channel size of 1.25 nm, which was consistent with the results calculated from the single-crystal data (C,D). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) chemical mapping showed a uniform distribution of Zr and Mn dispersed in the NMOFs (E). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) patterns disclosed that Zr, Mn, C, N, and O were successfully integrated in the NMOFs (Figure S2). The structure of the NMOFs was also confirmed by the comparison between powder XRD patterns of the NMOFs and their simulated data (Figure S3). Concisely matched peaks in small angle sections validated that the crystal structure was maintained in the NMOFs. The composition of the NMOFs was investigated using ICP–AES and TGA (Figure S4). The Zr/Mn ratio in the NMOFs was determined to be 2:1, and the calculated formula was Zr6C144H72N12O24Mn3 (Table S1). Moreover, the NMOFs dispersed well in water to form a transparent solution for their real applications (F).

A relatively narrow size distribution was observed with the diameter of 224.3 nm from their DLS test (Figure S1). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) patterns disclosed that Zr, Mn, C, N, and O were successfully integrated in the NMOFs (Figure S2). The structure of the NMOFs was also confirmed by the comparison between powder XRD patterns of the NMOFs and their simulated data (Figure S3). elements.content: N2 sorption measurements at 77 K were performed to assess the porosities of the NMOFs (A,B). The experimental BET surface area of the NMOFs was calculated to be ∼1900 m2/g, and its pore volume was ∼0.67 cm3/g. The pore with a size of 1.26 nm was observed and consistent with the results from the experimental result and theoretical prediction (C,D). The UV–vis absorption spectra of the TCPP ligand, Mn-TCPP ligand, and the NMOFs were recorded (C). The Mn-TCPP ligand showed a strong peak at 466 nm and two peaks for the Q band after chelating metal Mn ions, different from free porphyrin molecule with one peak at 414 nm for the Soret band and the four characteristic absorption peaks at 500–700 nm for the Q band (D). The NMOFs exhibited a similar pattern to the Mn-TCPP, with some red shifting at 476 nm for the Soret band and two peaks at 573 and 603 nm for the Q band, which indicated that Mn-porphyrin was efficiently integrated into the frameworks.

elements.content: The NMOFs were thiol-functionalized to obtain NMOF–SH via a simple silanization procedure for the integration of NO precursor molecules through the reaction between thiol (−SH) groups and t-butyl nitrite. The morphology of NMOF–SNO was observed from their TEM images (Figure S5). The DLS diameter of the NMOF–SNO was 265.5 nm (Figure S6). The EDS elemental mapping data clearly displayed that zirconium, manganese, silicon, nitrogen, and sulfur were successfully integrated into NMOF–SNO (Figure S7). The conjugation of the −SNO groups on the NMOF–SH was also confirmed with the characteristic peaks of −CH2–S–, −NO, and −S–N at 1298, 1511, and 794 cm–1, respectively, in the FTIR spectra (Figure S8). To illustrate the structure and elemental distribution of the NMOF–SNO, XPS patterns were recorded (Figure S9). The peaks at 224 and 160 eV in wide-scan XPS spectra undoubtedly disclose the presence of Zr and Mn from the NMOFs, whereas the peaks of Si 2p, S 2p, and N 1s are also observed. TGA was utilized to study the component of different nanocomposites (Figure S10). Before 300 °C, the weight loss was ascribed to the removal of the solvent molecules. On the basis of the weight-losing ratio obtained from the TGA result, the mass ratio of the SNO shell in the nanocomposites was calculated to be 25.4%. All of the evidence illustrated that SNO was successfully conjugated onto the NMOFs.

elements.content: The vis–NIR spectra of NMOF–SNO at different concentrations were recorded (Figure S11). Considering the deeper penetration into the tissue and less damage to surrounding tissues, we selected an 808 nm NIR laser to study the PTT property. The in vitro photothermal property of NMOF–SNO was studied by measuring the temperature of the solution under NIR laser irradiation (808 nm, 1 W cm–2, 600 s). The temperature enhanced with the increase of the nanocomposite concentration, exposure time, and NIR laser power (A,B). To validate the photothermal stability of the NMOF–SNO nanocomposites to respond to the photoexcitation, five cycles of laser on/off with an 808 nm laser were recorded (C). The consistent temperature elevation was observed, indicating the high NIR photothermal stability of NMOF–SNO composites. The photothermal capacity was recorded with an IR thermal imaging camera. As shown in D, NMOF–SNO solution at the concentration of 400 μg mL–1 was quickly enhanced to 54 °C after light irradiation for 8 min. The elevated temperature was three times higher than that of the saline solution, so NMOF–SNO was efficient to change NIR light into heat. The photothermal conversion efficiency of NMOF–SNO was 48.3%, which was calculated precisely (Figure S12). The efficiency was better than those of Bi2S3 (28.1%), Au nanorods (22.0%), and MoS2 (34.5%), possibly because of the high molar extinction coefficient (Figure S13), manifesting the potential of NMOF–SNO as a photothermal agent for NO generation and PTT.

elements.content: T 1-weighted MRI was performed to estimate the property of NMOF–SNO for theranostic applications. The NMOFs exhibited the r 1 value of 26.9 mM–1 s–1, higher than that of previous Mn-porphyrin composites (Table S2). The high dispersibility of Mn in the frameworks was attributed to the good T 1-weighted imaging capacity of the NMOF core (A). The diffusion of water molecules was promoted by the mesopores, improving the ability of Mn ions to approach water molecules for efficient T 1-weighted MRI. The relaxation rate of NMOF–SNO had linear change with their increasing concentration. The longitudinal relaxivity value (r 1) was 24.6 mM–1 s–1, whereas the r 2 value of NMOF–SNO was 12.1 mM–1 s–1 (Figure S14). Thus, NMOF–SNO is very suitable for T 1-weighted MRI. The T 1-weighted MR efficiency of NMOF–SNO was confirmed by the apparent Mn concentration-reliant brightening property (inset of A).

elements.content: The release of NO, which was triggered by heat in aqueous solution, was tested by a typical Griess assay. NMOF–SNO and NMOF solutions (400 μg mL–1 based on NMOFs) were irradiated under an 808 nm laser for 10 min. No NO gas was observed from single NMOFs, and only little NO gas was detected from NMOF–SNO without laser irradiation. However, NO was generated from NMOF–SNO quickly and strongly to respond to the NIR laser irradiation at a power density of 1 W cm–2 (B). Thus, the NO release belonged to the breakage of S–NO triggered by the high temperature of the NMOF. The intracellular production of NO was verified by an NO probe, DAFDA, which reacts with NO to generate intense fluorescence. As observed in C, the cells cultured with NMOF–SNO showed weak fluorescence compared to the NMOF group. After irradiation with a NIR laser, the cells treated with NMOF–SNO gave out brilliant green color, confirming the generation of plenty of NO.
elements.clean_text:
Controlled in Vitro Release of NO

The release of NO, which was triggered by heat in aqueous solution, was tested by a typical Griess assay. NMOF-SNO and NMOF solutions (400 μg mL-1 based on NMOFs) were irradiated under an 808 nm laser for 10 min. No NO gas was observed from single NMOFs, and only little NO gas was detected from NMOF-SNO without laser irradiation. However, NO was generated from NMOF-SNO quickly and strongly to respond to the NIR laser irradiation at a power density of 1 W cm-2 (B). Thus, the NO release belonged to the breakage of S-NO triggered by the high temperature of the NMOF. The intracellular production of NO was verified by an NO probe, DAFDA, which reacts with NO to generate intense fluorescence. As observed in C, the cells cultured with NMOF-SNO showed weak fluorescence compared to the NMOF group. After irradiation with a NIR laser, the cells treated with NMOF-SNO gave out brilliant green color, confirming the generation of plenty of NO.

elements.content: To estimate the synergic treatment effects of NMOF–SNO, their cytotoxicity was evaluated using MCF-7 cells as a model by the MTT assay (A,B). More than 90% MCF-7 cells were alive when cultured with 200 μg mL–1 NMOF–SNO or NMOFs (based on NMOFs), which was due to the low toxicity of the nanocomposites. To further demonstrate the cell entry efficiency of NMOF and NMOF–SNO, we investigate the cellular internalization of NMOF and NMOF–SNO. As shown in Figure S15, the intracellular Mn content in the cells treated with NMOF was almost the same with that of the cells treated with NMOF–SNO, which indicates the same cell entry efficiency. By contrast, the cells cultured with single NMOFs and then subjected to laser irradiation revealed obvious apoptosis to confirm the PTT efficiency. The lower cell viability at a high concentration of NMOF–SNO demonstrated a significant effect from the NO and photothermal synergetic therapy. Because NO gas at a low concentration has been reported as a signal molecule, we speculate that NO at low concentration does not have a cytostatic effect on tumor cells and the release of less NO hardly affects the cell viability. The confocal laser scanning microcopy images revealed that NMOF–SNO was endocytosed into the cells as observed from red fluorescence stemmed from Cy5-tagged NMOF–SNO after 2 h incubation (C). Moreover, the intensity of fluorescence became intensive with the prolonged time of 4 h.

More than 90% MCF-7 cells were alive when cultured with 200 μg mL-1 NMOF-SNO or NMOFs (based on NMOFs), which was due to the low toxicity of the nanocomposites. To further demonstrate the cell entry efficiency of NMOF and NMOF-SNO, we investigate the cellular internalization of NMOF and NMOF-SNO. As shown in Figure S15, the intracellular Mn content in the cells treated with NMOF was almost the same with that of the cells treated with NMOF-SNO, which indicates the same cell entry efficiency. By contrast, the cells cultured with single NMOFs and then subjected to laser irradiation revealed obvious apoptosis to confirm the PTT efficiency. The lower cell viability at a high concentration of NMOF-SNO demonstrated a significant effect from the NO and photothermal synergetic therapy. Because NO gas at a low concentration has been reported as a signal molecule, we speculate that NO at low concentration does not have a cytostatic effect on tumor cells and the release of less NO hardly affects the cell viability. The confocal laser scanning microcopy images revealed that NMOF-SNO was endocytosed into the cells as observed from red fluorescence stemmed from Cy5-tagged NMOF-SNO after 2 h incubation (C). elements.content: Trypan blue experiment was used to further verify the synergetic treatment efficiency of NMOF–SNO. Dead cells were dyed by trypan blue and differentiated easily from the normal cells. Vast majority of cells were alive for the control group with single laser illumination (Figure S16), so the laser power is sufficiently safe to the cells. Besides, about 95% of the cells were alive observed from the NMOF–SNO group without NIR irradiation. For comparison, the cell viability in the NMOF group became only 50% under laser irradiation to illustrate the efficiency of single PTT. The viability decreased to approximately 20% for the cells treated with the treatment of NMOF–SNO after NIR light irradiation. The efficient cell-killing ability of NMOF–SNO + NIR confirmed the synergistic effect of NO and PTT.

elements.content: The T 1-weighted MRI potential was investigated with mice as models after NMOF–SNO solution was intravenously injected. The kidney and liver were evidently distinguished, thanks to the good spatial resolution of MRI. As shown in A, the dramatic bright signal was noticed in the liver and kidney part 1 h postinjection. The signal of both the liver and kidney region decreased 24 h postinjection (B). Moreover, the MRI of the liver region in the axial plane exhibited an obvious signal change. The consistent results were observed from the MCF-7 tumor-burdened mice for the accumulation in liver and kidney, whereas the tumor was obviously visualized after the intravenous injection of NMOF–SNO (C). The strong signal enhancement in the tumor was revealed from the MR images, manifesting good tumor targeting of NMOF–SNO (D). Therefore, NMOF–SNO clustered at the tumor site by the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect.

elements.content: Except for MRI, the in vivo behavior of NMOF–SNO was also quantitatively tested by measuring the content of Mn in main organs using ICP–AES. The tumor accumulation of NMOF–SNO was high at 24 h postinjection, which was about 4.5% ID/g. The passive tumor targeting of NMOF–SNO should belong to the EPR effect of tumor tissues (Figure S17). For the sake of further studying the excretion kinetics, normal nude mice after intravenous injection of NMOF–SNO were sacrificed, and the Mn content was analyzed by ICP–AES. The accumulation of Mn in liver and spleen was ∼8.5 and ∼8% ID/g after 24 h postinjection and went down very low afterward. In particular, kidneys brought out high Mn signals exactly as shown in MRI, implying that NMOF–SNO could be removed via kidney (E). Later, the Mn content in urinary and feces was detected by ICP–AES. It is calculated that 18 and 6% ID of Mn were excreted by urinary and feces at the beginning day. High content of Mn was found primarily in the urinary in the next days (F). Therefore, the NMOF–SNO composites were excreted by renal excretion.
elements.clean_text: Except for MRI, the in vivo behavior of NMOF-SNO was also quantitatively tested by measuring the content of Mn in main organs using ICP-AES. The tumor accumulation of NMOF-SNO was high at 24 h postinjection, which was about 4.5% ID/g. The passive tumor targeting of NMOF-SNO should belong to the EPR effect of tumor tissues (Figure S17). For the sake of further studying the excretion kinetics, normal nude mice after intravenous injection of NMOF-SNO were sacrificed, and the Mn content was analyzed by ICP-AES. The accumulation of Mn in liver and spleen was ~8.5 and ~8% ID/g after 24 h postinjection and went down very low afterward. In particular, kidneys brought out high Mn signals exactly as shown in MRI, implying that NMOF-SNO could be removed via kidney (E). Later, the Mn content in urinary and feces was detected by ICP-AES. It is calculated that 18 and 6% ID of Mn were excreted by urinary and feces at the beginning day. High content of Mn was found primarily in the urinary in the next days (F). Therefore, the NMOF-SNO composites were excreted by renal excretion.

elements.content: Inspired by its excellent tumor accumulation, NMOF–SNO was used for in vivo MRI-guided tumor treatment. The MCF-7 tumor-bearing mice were chosen as the model. To monitor the photothermal effect generated from NMOF–SNO, an IR camera was used to record the temperature change of the tumor site after intravenous injection and exposure to the NIR laser (A). In the case of NMOF–SNO injection, the temperature of the tumor site enhanced to 54 °C quickly in 8 min. The excellent temperature increase was perfect for the ablation of tumor and NO release. The negligible temperature change of the group injected with the saline was observed. The photothermal capacity of NMOF–SNO also confirmed the potential for the effective release of NO under 808 nm irradiation.
elements.clean_text:
In Vivo NO and Photothermal Synergetic Therapy

Inspired by its excellent tumor accumulation, NMOF-SNO was used for in vivo MRI-guided tumor treatment. The MCF-7 tumor-bearing mice were chosen as the model. To monitor the photothermal effect generated from NMOF-SNO, an IR camera was used to record the temperature change of the tumor site after intravenous injection and exposure to the NIR laser (A). In the case of NMOF-SNO injection, the temperature of the tumor site enhanced to 54 °C quickly in 8 min. The excellent temperature increase was perfect for the ablation of tumor and NO release. The negligible temperature change of the group injected with the saline was observed. The photothermal capacity of NMOF-SNO also confirmed the potential for the effective release of NO under 808 nm irradiation.

elements.content: (A) IR thermal images of tumor-bearing mice to reveal temperature changes after injected with NMOF–SNO or saline. The images were recorded after the tumor sites exposed to an 808 nm laser. The arrows refer to the tumor site. (B) Tumor growth inhibition curve after different treatments. V 0 and V refer to tumor volumes before and after each treatment (**p < 0.01; ***p < 0.001). (C) Photos of the mice and tumors in each group after different treatments. (D) Changes of the tumor weight after different treatments. (E) Histological analysis of the tumor tissue. The black arrow points to the necrosis part of the tumor. The scale bar is 20 μm. (1) Saline as the control; (2) single NMOF–SNO injection; (3) single laser irradiation; (4) NMOFs after laser irradiation for PTT; and (5) NMOF–SNO after laser irradiation for NO + PTT synergetic treatment.
elements.clean_text: 7  (A) IR thermal images of tumor-bearing mice to reveal temperature changes after injected with NMOF-SNO or saline. The images were recorded after the tumor sites exposed to an 808 nm laser. The arrows refer to the tumor site. (B) Tumor growth inhibition curve after different treatments. V 0 and V refer to tumor volumes before and after each treatment (**p < 0.01; ***p < 0.001). (C) Photos of the mice and tumors in each group after different treatments. (D) Changes of the tumor weight after different treatments. (E) Histological analysis of the tumor tissue. The black arrow points to the necrosis part of the tumor. The scale bar is 20 μm. (1) Saline as the control; (2) single NMOF-SNO injection; (3) single laser irradiation; (4) NMOFs after laser irradiation for PTT; and (5) NMOF-SNO after laser irradiation for NO + PTT synergetic treatment.

elements.content: To investigate the in vivo cooperative efficiency of NO and PTT, MCF-7 tumor-burdened mice were separated into five groups. The negative control group was injected with saline. The NMOF–SNO–injected mice without laser irradiation and the mice with only NIR stimulation were considered as the positive control. In the PTT group, the mice after injection with NMOFs were exposed to the NIR laser for 10 min. The synergetic NO and PTT group was injected with NMOF–SNO and irradiated under an 808 nm laser (1.0 W cm–2, 10 min). The relative tumor sizes and tumor weights of all the groups are illustrated in B–D to confirm the cancer therapeutic effect. The tumor volume results revealed that NMOF–SNO, in combination with laser irradiation, exhibited the highest therapeutic efficiency compared with single PTT treatment. Therefore, our NMOF-based theranostic agent achieved a synergistic antitumor effect. Additionally, the mice weights of all groups were maintained after prolonged therapy, so the NMOF theranostic agent showed good biocompatibility and safety (Figure S18).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the in vivo cooperative efficiency of NO and PTT, MCF-7 tumor-burdened mice were separated into five groups. The negative control group was injected with saline. The NMOF-SNO-injected mice without laser irradiation and the mice with only NIR stimulation were considered as the positive control. In the PTT group, the mice after injection with NMOFs were exposed to the NIR laser for 10 min. The synergetic NO and PTT group was injected with NMOF-SNO and irradiated under an 808 nm laser (1.0 W cm-2, 10 min). The relative tumor sizes and tumor weights of all the groups are illustrated in B-D to confirm the cancer therapeutic effect. The tumor volume results revealed that NMOF-SNO, in combination with laser irradiation, exhibited the highest therapeutic efficiency compared with single PTT treatment. Therefore, our NMOF-based theranostic agent achieved a synergistic antitumor effect. Additionally, the mice weights of all groups were maintained after prolonged therapy, so the NMOF theranostic agent showed good biocompatibility and safety (Figure S18).

elements.content: Not only the tumor sizes were the assessment indicator of tumor treatment effect, but histologic analysis could also explain the extent of dead cancer cells. The tumors of all the groups were removed after 14 days’ treatment, which were ready for H&E histologic analysis (E). The tumor cells grew quickly, and no sign of necrosis was observed in the negative and positive groups. Extensive necrosis area in the tumor site of the PTT group was apparently stained by eosin. Moreover, over 90% necrotic cancer cells were dyed by eosin in the dual-therapy group. The results of H&E histologic analysis were in agreement with the tumor suppressive effect of different groups. The normal tissues of the mice after the treatment had no pathological change as shown by the results of histologic analysis (Figure S19). Thus, our nanocomposites were safe for in vivo applications.

elements.content: Inspired by the satisfactory results in the combination therapy in vivo, we further investigate the efficiency of the cotherapy compared to traditional chemotherapy. To simulate the drug resistance of the tumor, the mice of both the control and experimental groups were first treated with low-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.2 mg mL–1) in early stage. Later on, the mice of the control group were administrated with high-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.6 mg mL–1) every other day (A). The mice of the experimental group were treated with NMOF–SNO + NIR every other day. Notably, the tumor growth of the experimental group was inhibited remarkably. Thus, NMOF–SNO enhanced the therapeutic effect significantly and was not affected by the drug resistance from DOX (B–C). The tumor of the experimental group was almost eliminated, whereas the tumor size of the control group increased continuously at the end of treatment, possibly because of drug resistance of the tumor. In addition, treatment with free DOX caused visible side effects, such as the loss of body weight, and the body weight of the mice treated with DOX + NMOF–SNO was in a normal trend (Figure S20). Pathology analysis was also employed to further investigate the antitumor efficiency. The tumor tissue treated with DOX + NMOF–SNO was obviously necrotic, whereas the control group was less necrotic (Figure S21). The result demonstrated that our nanocomposites exhibited high treatment efficiency compared to chemotherapy.
elements.clean_text:
Treatment Efficiency of NMOF-SNO Compared to Free DOX

Inspired by the satisfactory results in the combination therapy in vivo, we further investigate the efficiency of the cotherapy compared to traditional chemotherapy. To simulate the drug resistance of the tumor, the mice of both the control and experimental groups were first treated with low-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.2 mg mL-1) in early stage. Later on, the mice of the control group were administrated with high-dose DOX (100 μL, 0.6 mg mL-1) every other day (A). The mice of the experimental group were treated with NMOF-SNO + NIR every other day. Notably, the tumor growth of the experimental group was inhibited remarkably. Thus, NMOF-SNO enhanced the therapeutic effect significantly and was not affected by the drug resistance from DOX (B-C). The tumor of the experimental group was almost eliminated, whereas the tumor size of the control group increased continuously at the end of treatment, possibly because of drug resistance of the tumor. In addition, treatment with free DOX caused visible side effects, such as the loss of body weight, and the body weight of the mice treated with DOX + NMOF-SNO was in a normal trend (Figure S20). Pathology analysis was also employed to further investigate the antitumor efficiency. The tumor tissue treated with DOX + NMOF-SNO was obviously necrotic, whereas the control group was less necrotic (Figure S21). The result demonstrated that our nanocomposites exhibited high treatment efficiency compared to chemotherapy.

elements.content: (A) Schematic illustration of the treatment of the free DOX-based control group and the DOX + NMOF–SNO experimental group. Low-dose DOX of 100 μL, 0.2 mg mL–1 to produce the mimic drug-resistance model. High-dose DOX of 100 μL, 0.6 mg mL–1 for the real treatment of the tumor. NMOF–SNO (400 μL, 1 mg mL–1) illustrated the efficiency of NO-photothermal synergistic therapy. (B) Photos of the tumor in each group after the treatment. (C) Tumor weight after different treatments (***p < 0.001).

(C) Tumor weight after different treatments (***p < 0.001).

elements.content: In summary, we for the first time developed a Mn-porphyrin NMOF platform for MRI-guided NO and photothermal synergetic therapy of cancer. The successful insertion of Mn ions into the porphyrin rings offers the NMOFs strong T 1-weighted MR contrast, high molar extinction coefficient, and effective photothermal stability. The heat-sensitive NO donor, SNO, was integrated on the NMOF to trigger controllable NO generation. With efficient MRI guidance, NO and photothermal synergetic therapy was obtained from the nanocomposites under single irradiation and validated with cells and mice as models. Besides, the NMOF–SNO composites exhibited high tumor inhibition efficiency compared to chemotherapy with DOX for a simple drug-resistance model. However, NO treatment is still in its infancy. The smart NO donors of the systems are naturally unstable, and the biological effects of NO therapy should be evaluated with further research. In spite of a few unresolved issues, the smart design of Mn-porphyrin NMOFs with MRI guided-NO and PTT synergistic therapy opens new avenues for next-generation tumor theranostics.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we for the first time developed a Mn-porphyrin NMOF platform for MRI-guided NO and photothermal synergetic therapy of cancer. The successful insertion of Mn ions into the porphyrin rings offers the NMOFs strong T 1-weighted MR contrast, high molar extinction coefficient, and effective photothermal stability. The heat-sensitive NO donor, SNO, was integrated on the NMOF to trigger controllable NO generation. With efficient MRI guidance, NO and photothermal synergetic therapy was obtained from the nanocomposites under single irradiation and validated with cells and mice as models. Besides, the NMOF-SNO composites exhibited high tumor inhibition efficiency compared to chemotherapy with DOX for a simple drug-resistance model. However, NO treatment is still in its infancy. The smart NO donors of the systems are naturally unstable, and the biological effects of NO therapy should be evaluated with further research. In spite of a few unresolved issues, the smart design of Mn-porphyrin NMOFs with MRI guided-NO and PTT synergistic therapy opens new avenues for next-generation tumor theranostics.

cln_elements.content: ZrCl4 (4.16 mg), MnTCPPCl (0.011 mmol L–1), and acetic acid (0.42 mL) were dissolved in 16 mL of DMF using a 20 mL Pyrex vial. Then, the mixture was heated at 120 °C in an air oven for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature, dark green fusiform-shaped NMOFs were obtained and collected by centrifugation (9 mg, 63% yield). Anal. Calcd (%) for NMOFs: C, 56%; H, 2.7%; N, 5.3%. Found: C, 54%; H, 4.3%; N, 4.6%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NMOFs and NMOF-SNO

ZrCl4 (4.16 mg), MnTCPPCl (0.011 mmol L-1), and acetic acid (0.42 mL) were dissolved in 16 mL of DMF using a 20 mL Pyrex vial. Then, the mixture was heated at 120 °C in an air oven for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature, dark green fusiform-shaped NMOFs were obtained and collected by centrifugation (9 mg, 63% yield). Anal. Calcd (%) for NMOFs: C, 56%; H, 2.7%; N, 5.3%. Found: C, 54%; H, 4.3%; N, 4.6%.

cln_elements.content:
N2 sorption measurements at 77 K were performed to assess the porosities of the NMOFs (A,B). The experimental BET surface area of the NMOFs was calculated to be ∼1900 m2/g, and its pore volume was ∼0.67 cm3/g. The pore with a size of 1.26 nm was observed and consistent with the results from the experimental result and theoretical prediction (C,D). The UV–vis absorption spectra of the TCPP ligand, Mn-TCPP ligand, and the NMOFs were recorded (C). The Mn-TCPP ligand showed a strong peak at 466 nm and two peaks for the Q band after chelating metal Mn ions, different from free porphyrin molecule with one peak at 414 nm for the Soret band and the four characteristic absorption peaks at 500–700 nm for the Q band (D). The NMOFs exhibited a similar pattern to the Mn-TCPP, with some red shifting at 476 nm for the Soret band and two peaks at 573 and 603 nm for the Q band, which indicated that Mn-porphyrin was efficiently integrated into the frameworks.

MR Property of NMOF–SNO

T 1-weighted MRI was performed to estimate the property of NMOF–SNO for theranostic applications. The NMOFs exhibited the r 1 value of 26.9 mM–1 s–1, higher than that of previous Mn-porphyrin composites (Table S2). The high dispersibility of Mn in the frameworks was attributed to the good T 1-weighted imaging capacity of the NMOF core (A). The diffusion of water molecules was promoted by the mesopores, improving the ability of Mn ions to approach water molecules for efficient T 1-weighted MRI. The relaxation rate of NMOF–SNO had linear change with their increasing concentration. The longitudinal relaxivity value (r 1) was 24.6 mM–1 s–1, whereas the r 2 value of NMOF–SNO was 12.1 mM–1 s–1 (Figure S14). Thus, NMOF–SNO is very suitable for T 1-weighted MRI. The T 1-weighted MR efficiency of NMOF–SNO was confirmed by the apparent Mn concentration-reliant brightening property (inset of A).
